0.text:
One of the great and slightly strange dangers
of falling in love with someone is how we

4.text:
may respond the day they start to love us
back. Some of the reasons we fall in love

10.text:
with people is because we long to escape from
ourselves into the embrace of a person who

16.text:
appears as beautiful, perfect and accomplished
as we feel ourselves to be flawed, dumb and

23.text:
mediocre. But what if such a being were one
day turn around and love us back? Nothing

29.text:
could discredit them faster. How could they
be as divine as we'd hoped for when they have

35.text:
the bad taste to approve of someone like us?
It turns out that one of the central requirements

42.text:
of a good relationship is a degree of affection
for ourselves; built up over the years, largely

49.text:
in childhood. We need a legacy of being deserving
of love in order not to respond very obtusely

56.text:
to the affections granted to us by adult partners.
Without a decent amount of self-love, the

62.text:
love of another person will always prove sickening
and misguided – and we will self-destructively

69.text:
– though unconsciously – set out to repel
or disappoint it. It will simply feel more

75.text:
normal and therefore comfortable to be disliked
or ignored when that is mostly what we have

81.text:
known. If we are not wholly convinced of our
own lovability, receiving affection can appear

88.text:
like being bestowed a prize for an accomplishment
we don’t feel we ever earned. People unfortunate

95.text:
enough to fall in love with self-hating types
must brace themselves for the recriminations

102.text: due to false flatterers. There is an old joke made by Groucho Marx about not deigning

108.text:
to belong to a club that would accept someone
like him as a member. We laugh at the Marxist

115.text:
position because of its absurd contradictions:
how is it possible that we should both wish

120.text:
to join a club, and yet lose that wish as
soon as it comes true? Why wouldn’t we just

125.text:
be happy to have been allowed into this club?
The answer lies in self-hatred; because for

132.text:
many of us, being accepted into a grand and
beautiful club doesn’t feel like what our

138.text:
inner psyches have been shaped to accept.
We wonder how we can continue to believe in

143.text:
a club, or indeed a beloved now that they
believe in us. There is usually a troubling

150.text:
Marxist moment in every relationship, a moment
when it becomes clear that love is going to

156.text:
be reciprocated; that we won’t simply admire
someone from afar without hope of mutuality.

162.text:
The way the crisis is resolved depends on the balance
between self-love and self-hatred in our own characters. If self-hatred

170.text:
gains the upper hand, then the one who is
being loved back will declare that the beloved

175.text:
(on some excuse or other) is just not good enough
for them (not good enough by virtue of associating

181.text:
with no-goods). But if self-love gains the
upper hand, then both partners may accept

187.text:
that seeing their love reciprocated is not
proof of how low the beloved is, but instead of how

194.text:
lovable they have themselves turned out to
be. It emerges that knowing how to love

201.text:
ourselves a little can be one of the kindest
and therefore most romantic things we can

207.text: ever learn to do for our partners.
